title: J.DepP - C++ implementation of Japanese Dependency Parsers

last_post.content:
@wim_v12e I know right, I think he hand-wrote that entire site 😳

Here's a GIF of me using my app for an example document after I'm done glossing it (this is Oshiri Tantei volume 3).

Every part of the gloss comes from some well-regarded internet database: vocabulary from JMdict, particles from Naoko Chino's book of particles, deconjugations largely from Taeko Kamiya's books on verbs and adjectives, kanji info from KanjiDic, etc.

In actually creating this gloss, the app gives me a firehose of possible items that might possibly be related to the text at hand. The second image is in this earlier, "glossing" mode that I have to go through to add the information in the first GIF.

MeCab+UniDic is pretty good. The main challenge is that the morphemes UniDic (or any training dictionary like IPADIC) use is not linked to any learner-friendly resource like JMdict or any grammar guide, obviously—MeCab is intended to be used for serious NLP work.

So my app uses MeCab, a bunsetsu chunker http://www.tkl.iis.u-tokyo.ac.jp/~ynaga/jdepp/ and a ton of carefully-crafted rules to suggest potential cross-references to JMdict and textbooks.

I've written code to help me make glosses like this for Mandarin and Cantonese text and it's a lot more straightforward to go from NLP parsers to dictionary glosses. Japanese agglutination is intricate enough that my app can't be very efficient in pointing me to exactly the definition or the deconjugation that it thinks I'll use. So glossing a single sentence like this is probably 25-50 clicks if all goes well (no words missing in the dictionary, no furigana mistakes I have to override, no deconjugations that aren't wrong), etc.

So I don't think it'd be appropriate for an LLM to try and create a gloss like this or like the Botchan site, but I do wonder how useful it'd be to help link entries from these very specific databases (JMdict, particles database, deconjugation rules) to morphemes here.

There's also a lot of design work I could do to make the glossing part of the app more ergonomic and efficient, like sort dictionary entries by how often I've used them previously in the doc (if not automatically add them) too.

#MeCab #Japanese #NLP

title: Cylindrical Shadows | MATH/ART BLOG

last_post.content:
Here's the link to the post. http://mathartblog.com/?p=696

Things I learned:
(1) Making things that look like pipes (walls with thickness) is harder than you'd think it would be;
(2) The final trick for making a printable object was to project the tiles to a point, and then join them to their bases to make conical solids, and *then* solid difference with the cylinder.

Before, I'd been trying to split the cylinder with open cones and join the pieces between the walls. It was fiddly and unreliable.

last_post.content:
This post by @jimniels resonates with me https://blog.jim-nielsen.com/2023/deadlines-as-technology/

I get a lot more done when I have a deadline, even if that's just "before we meet next week". I have an ever-growing TODO list of things to play with, try out, dig deeper into, but unless any of them *need* to be done they all just sit in that list. I don't recall where I saw it, but I like the idea of having two lists: "things to find time to take care of" and "things time has taken care of". Deadlines can trigger the transition.
